newsitem.title: USA: HealthSouth acquiring Horizon/CMS for $900 million plus debt.
newsitem.headline: HealthSouth acquiring Horizon/CMS for $900 million plus debt.

text.p: BIRMINGHAM)
By David Morgan

In a deal combining the nation's two largest networks of rehabilitation centres, HealthSouth Corp. said Tuesday it was acquiring Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corp. for about $900 million in stock and the assumption of about $700 million in debt.

HealthSouth, which became the United States' largest provider of outpatient health care services mainly through acquisitions, said Horizon/CMS stockholders would receive 0.42169 share of HealthSouth for each share of Horizon they own.
The deal was expected to close at midyear, barring regulatory delay by U.S. antitrust officials.
Horizon's stock jumped $2.50 to $16.75 on the New York Stock Exchange after the deal was announced. Stock in HealthSouth, which also trades on the NYSE, slipped $2.25 to $40.875.
The combined company will have one-fourth of U.S. outpatient rehabilitation centres and almost two-thirds of all 190 rehabilitation hospitals.
The acquisition of Horizon/CMS will also add 12 new markets in which the merged company can provide outpatient surgery and rehabilitation services.
"If we were to go out and try to build this network that we're acquiring, it'd take a lifetime," HealthSouth Chairman Richard Scrushy told reporters and Wall Street analysts in a conference call.
"Once we own these hospitals and these outpatient centres, that pretty much shuts out any other health care company from ever getting into our business in a significant way."
Annual revenues for the new company would reach about $5 billion at the outset.
Industry analysts said that while the deal would allow a reduction in costs for the combined company, increasing its revenues would present more of a challenge over a longer period.
"The easiest part to accomplish is the cost-cutting side, and some of that you can probably accomplish in the first six months after you close the deal," said brokerage PaineWebber's Helen O'Donnell.

"Then the other part is building the revenue side, which is where they bring their contracts to Horizon hospitals, and that'll take a longer time to build. They'll start getting some benefits in about 12 months."
Scrushy said that by purchasing Horizon, HeathSouth was acquiring access to 50 major metropolitan areas where it had often been kept out by existing franchise agreements.
New markets would enable HealthSouth to wring new business out of existing contracts with national corporate clients, including Wal-Mart Stores Inc., Marriott International Inc. and The Coca-Cola Co.

Scrushy also said the acquisition puts HealthSouth in a position to take full advantage of expected reforms in Medicare, which he said would base the federally sponsored health-care programme for 30 million elderly Americans on a managed-care model.
He said the anticipated reforms would for the first time allow companies like his to begin making money from treating Medicare patients.
"As we see Medicare recipients move into a managed-care environment, we're going to be sitting there in every major city in America positioned to contract for it," he said.

"Hopefully, over the next 10 years in every major city with all services ... that would generate about $25 billion (in) sales. And that's our goal -- to build a company that is in every major market."

Horizon, based in Albuquerque, N.M., owns, leases or manages 267 long-term care facilities, a contract therapy business holding 1,400 contracts, an institutional pharmacy business serving 38,500 beds, and other health care services.

However, the company also has had legal, financial and regulatory problems in recent years. Just last week it agreed to spend $20 million to settle a stockholders lawsuit alleging insider trading by some officials.
In December, Horizon paid $5.8 million to state and federal authorities to resolve allegations of billing fraud.
HealthSouth, based in Birmingham, Ala., said it expects the acquisition to add to its earnings per share this year.
Neal Elliott, Horizon's chairman and chief executive, will join HealthSouth's board upon the merger's completion, which is expected this summer.
